text:
Hummingbirds do
everything in a hurry.

When they drink nectar,
their tongue

flicks in and out
15 times a second, or faster.

The nectar rushes up two
grooves in the bird’s tongue,
which is split like a snake’s.

That was thought to happen
through capillary action,

the way liquid moves up a
narrow straw without suction.

say that’s not
how it works.

Using feeders set up
in natural environments

and high-speed video, they
showed that the tongue
works like a kind of pump.

In the bird’s beak, the
tongue is compressed,

and it stays that
way as it shoots out.

Once it reaches the
nectar, it springs open,

and that rapid expansion
draws up the fluid.

It’s a new wrinkle in the
evolution of birds, flowers
